Statistical Concepts assignment

Author

Huzzaifa Khan 

library(dplyr)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union
random_vars <- readRDS("C:/Users/huzai/OneDrive/Documents/GitHub/tes/cdsba-cdx3745/content/Causal_Data_Science_Data/Causal_Data_Science_Data/random_vars.rds")
View(random_vars)

Assignment 1:

sampleSize <- 1000
expected_age <- mean(random_vars[1:sampleSize, "age"])
expected_income <- mean(random_vars[1:sampleSize, "income"])
print(paste("Expected age =",expected_age, "Expected income =",expected_income))
#> [1] "Expected age = 33.471 Expected income = 3510.731"
print(paste("Variance for age =" ,var(random_vars[1:sampleSize,"age"]), "Variance for income =",var(random_vars[1:sampleSize,"income"])))
#> [1] "Variance for age = 340.607766766767 Variance for income = 8625645.84448348"
print(paste("standard deviation for age =" ,sd(random_vars[1:sampleSize,"age"]), "standard deviation for income =",sd(random_vars[1:sampleSize,"income"])))
#> [1] "standard deviation for age = 18.4555619466536 standard deviation for income = 2936.94498492626"

Assignment 2:

Standard deviations individually for both random variables tells us that how the values tends to spread out or vary from the expected value. However comparison for both might not be useful enough to have some insight as there are other useful metrics like correlation and covariance which might be more useful to find a relation.

Assignment 3 :

Cov_XY = cov(random_vars[1:sampleSize,"age"],random_vars[1:sampleSize,"income"])
Corr_Xy = cor(random_vars[1:sampleSize,"age"],random_vars[1:sampleSize,"income"])
print(paste("Covariance =",Cov_XY, "Correlation =",Corr_Xy))
#> [1] "Covariance = 29700.1468458458 Correlation = 0.547943162326477"

Assignment 4 :

For better interpretation, correlation is preferable as compared to the covariance as it gives a bird eye view from it’s correlation coefficient ranging from -1 to 1. It checks the linear dependence between 2 RV’s.

Assignment 5 :

income_under_18 <- random_vars %>% filter(age <= 18)
print(paste("Conditional Expected value given age under 18 =",mean(income_under_18$income)))
#> [1] "Conditional Expected value given age under 18 = 389.607438016529"
income_bw_18to65 <- random_vars %>% filter(age >= 18 & age <=65)
print(paste("Conditional Expected value given age between 18 and 65 =",mean(income_bw_18to65$income)))
#> [1] "Conditional Expected value given age between 18 and 65 = 4691.3779637378"
income_over_65 <- random_vars %>% filter(age >=65)
print(paste("Conditional Expected value given age over 65 =",mean(income_over_65$income)))
#> [1] "Conditional Expected value given age over 65 = 1777.23728813559"
